This means 3 Hezbollah members have now been convicted in the Hariri assassination - Salim Ayyash, who led the assassination team, and Merhi and Oneissi.

Oh wow, the Hariri tribunal appeals chamber today reversed the acquittals of 2 Hezbollah members in the Rafik Hariri assassination. The 2, Hassan Merhi and Hussein Oneissi, were accused of orchestrating the false claim of responsibility after the attack to blame it on al Qaeda.

Thank you for coming to my TED talk

Yes there is racism in Europe's sudden compassion for refugees coming from a white, Christian country, but the racism and prejudice is far closer to home than we portray in the midst of our victimization narrative.

Or take the fact that the Gulf countries, the wealthiest states in the region and connected by blood, tribe, culture and faith, took pretty much 0 refugees in, despite their active involvement in the war.

Or take the way Syrian refugees were treated and the racism they were subjected to in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, constantly abused, disenfranchised, stripped of their rights, and blamed for the economic mismanagement by Erdogan and Lebanon's politicians.
Take for example the way Iraqi refugees, particularly the women who were forced into prostitution, were treated when they fled to Syria after the American invasion.

Since we're firing on all cylinders today I need to point out one thing in the whole racism debate about Ukraine that needs to be said: we need to be conscious of the way we treated refugees in so-called Arab and Muslim countries before we reprimand Europe for its actions.

Thank you to everyone who has written for us. And keep pitching us. Tell us more of your stories.

We can all still do better. We can have more writers from the region cover their societies, which has been one of our top priorities from day 1. We can give more space to stories that aren't guns and bullets, to the tapestries weaved from our collective experiences.

But when we did, we also wanted to show that we can all do better, that legacy media can tell better, more nuanced stories. And it's worked. Media outlets in the region are following our coverage, citing it, and adapting the format, and publishing our writers.

My job is to recruit writers, read their fascinating stories, coach and guide them, and then have the whole world read the thing that has just floored me with its wit and curiosity. It's the best job in the world, journalism.

I'm grateful for being part of such a talented, passionate, and hilarious team (notwithstanding @FaisalAlYafai's pun game). It has been a solace in the darkest moments of the past year and a half because what we craft every day is meaningful and beautiful.
A year later we have advanced that goal considerably, building a magazine that has published some of the most interesting, thought-provoking, and newsmaking stories from the Middle East and beyond.

When we started this magazine, it was with the idea that we could all do better. That there were so many stories left untold in legacy media in our part of the world. That the stories that did get told only offered a glimpse into the rich tapestry of our world and societies.

Today the incredible @newlinesmag has turned one year old. It's been the honor of my career to be part of the team that founded this magazine, based on the vision of a longtime friend and visionary, called @hxhassan.

@tgoudsouzian I don't think it's the right thing to do in any context, and I don't have an issue with French being required in schools. It's the stubborn attempt to make life more difficult for people who speak the other official language of the country, due to a false victimhood status.
@tgoudsouzian Except the comparison is backwards. They are doing the thing that made those minorities leave their home countries. Albeit with less murder.
@tgoudsouzian Hunter gatherer tribes in the Amazon - their culture is endangered. Not a language with 400 million speakers globally, most of whom had it forced upon them by colonial masters.

@tgoudsouzian French is the dominant language in the province. Even Montreal is only sort of bilingual. But no this is a great way to preserve one's culture. Maybe when people come to the Arab world we should impose a blanket Arabic-only rule and make everyone wear veils or grow beards.

@tgoudsouzian Even things as basic as comms about public roadworks in front of the house are exclusively in French. There is no reason that should be the case in a country with 2 official languages. It's basically deliberate alienation.

@tgoudsouzian They can protect their heritage without forcing it down the throats of everyone. There is no reason in a country with 2 official languages that my wife had to give birth and spend 2 days at hospital without the benefit of a single English speaking nurse.

I'm actually seriously contemplating moving out of Montreal/Quebec because of how much of a pain in the ass the province makes it to get anything done in English in the interest of preserving a language that is globally pervasive because of French colonial brutality.

Why is French, which has speakers across France's former colonial possessions, the language that always feels like it's under threat of extinction and is constantly precious about its cultural heritage? Nothing makes me not want to learn French as much as French chauvinism.

In about 45 mins, @AlHudoodNet will livestream its annual awards show for the worst in Arab journalism, highlighting hate speech, sectarianism, disinfo, and other abuses by loyalist media. Tune in to this grand experiment here (it's also hilarious) https://t.co/Q1cxEcGtAd

We're all exhausted by the pandemic. But I hope findings like this will spur some much-needed reflection on what journalism becomes when it stops being about the facts and becomes about catering to the anxieties of a specific class of Western consumers.

There are many charitable explanations. But disaster porn is the clickbait equivalent of right-wing media's racism and hate speech. Its clicks similarly create panic and framing is designed for maximum user engagement. It comes from a better place, but has similar outcomes.

And it's precisely in moments of panic when I look to newspapers to be shepherds of public opinion with sober analysis and explanation and, dare I say, reassurance about the world. And yet this trafficking in disaster porn was absolutely relentless and permeated everything.
I don't really know what's the impetus behind the focus on disaster porn. Yes it was a very uncertain first few weeks, but we reached a modus vivendi with the virus after that.

I'm a serial subscriber to media outlets, whether international, Canadian, local, issue-based, Arab, magazines, digital/print, newsletters, etc., and my work over past 3 years was with indie and emerging, so I know all about challenges facing media outlets in Mideast and in West

I'm an individual obviously, but I have to say that my media consumption habits changed drastically as a result of the pandemic, and the change has mostly, unfortunately, been the elimination of left-leaning media outlets from my subscriptions due to relentless disaster porn.

e.g. excessive alarmism over infection rates, focusing on areas w/ high rates when overall numbers are going down, muted coverage of vaccines and other advances. I've long felt this way anecdotally, and was attacked for expressing this viewpoint on multiple occasions.

A couple of days ago, the NYT published in its morning newsletter commentary about the findings of a study into COVID-19 coverage by media outlets in the US, which found that the coverage was excessively negative to the point of being an outlier on the global stage.

It really transformed my media subscription/consumption patterns. I'm a serial subscriber to intl, local, indie, newsletter media, and pandemic disaster porn hugely reduced the share of traditional left-leaning media in my diet, even though we have similar worldviews.

NYT morning newsletter yesterday wrote about a study on how US media excessively focused on negative COVID news. Got attacked for saying it was disaster porn before, and have to say it prompted me to unsub from many outlets I used to like in favor of more sober coverage.

The toughest newsletter I have yet to be able to unsubscribe from is the press releases of Saad Hariri's office. Been trying to unsubscribe for almost 3 years now since leaving the Middle East to no avail. It even somehow makes it through junk mail filters.
